Ah, offshore accounts and tax havens — the Swiss Army knives of tax optimization, if you will. Let me tell you, when you're representing ultra-high-net-worth individuals, the key is not just to avoid taxes, but to do it with such elegance and legal plausibility that the IRS, HMRC, or any other tax authority would need a magnifying glass and a PhD in obscure tax law to even question it.

First and foremost, I always start with jurisdictional strategy. I look for countries with robust privacy laws, low or zero tax rates on foreign income, and — ideally — no automatic exchange of information with other countries. Places like the British Virgin Islands, the Cayman Islands, or even certain parts of the Middle East are where the real magic happens. These jurisdictions are like the quiet corners of the financial world where the rules are written in a language only the most sophisticated lawyers and accountants can decipher.

Now, the structure is everything. I don’t just set up a shell company and call it a day. No, no, no. That’s how you end up on a list. I use multi-layered holding companies. A private trust in the BVI, holding a company in the Caymans, which owns a company in the Netherlands, which then invests in the US or wherever the asset is. Each layer serves a purpose — asset protection, privacy, and tax efficiency. The Netherlands is particularly useful for its participation exemption regime, which allows for dividend income to be received tax-free under the right circumstances.

Then there’s the use of private foundations. These are often set up in jurisdictions like Liechtenstein or the Netherlands Antilles. They offer a unique blend of asset protection and tax neutrality. A private foundation can hold assets in a way that’s not easily traceable back to the individual, and in many cases, the foundation itself is not subject to income tax because it doesn’t have members or shareholders — it has a board of directors, which is usually the family or a trusted third party.

I also make heavy use of private equity and real estate investment structures. By placing assets into offshore funds or structured investment vehicles, I can leverage the tax treaties between countries and the fact that many of these vehicles are not subject to tax in their jurisdiction of incorporation. The idea is to route income through these structures in a way that it never technically becomes taxable income in the individual's home country.
